explanation:
To decide whether any part of UT_BSP_DoText is provably unreachable you must know the concrete values and types that control the function’s conditional and switch branches:

- BSP_UT_Global (variable/struct): the global object that contains CurrVerbosity — needed to determine whether the outer "if (MsgEnabled & 1)" region can ever be entered or is compile-time fixed (making that whole block unreachable).
- BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity (field and its compile-time/init value): the numeric value(s) or initialization of CurrVerbosity determine MsgEnabled = CurrVerbosity >> MessageType and therefore whether MsgEnabled & 1 or MsgEnabled <= 1 can ever be true; if CurrVerbosity is a compile‑time constant the guarded block may be provably dead.
- type/bit‑width of BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity: to reason about the definedness and results of the right-shift by MessageType (and whether shifts may always yield zero for the MessageType range), and thus whether conditions that depend on MsgEnabled are ever true.
- UTASSERT_CASETYPE_* enumerators (ABORT, FAILURE, MIR, WARN, TSF, TTF, BEGIN, PASS): the integer values of these case labels are required to determine which switch cases are mutually exclusive, overlap, or impossible for a given MessageType domain — used to determine whether any switch arms are unreachable and whether the final "if (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT)" can ever be true.
- OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_* constants (NORMAL, HIGHLIGHT, RED, GREEN, BLUE): numeric values for these macros/consts are required to check whether assignments/comparisons involving TermModeBits (e.g. TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL) can ever be true or are redundant/always false, which would make the associated ConsoleSetMode and resetting calls unreachable.
- OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl (signature/attributes, e.g. noreturn): whether this callee is declared non‑returning affects reachability reasoning in callers (and may make code after a call unreachable in other contexts). Knowing if it never returns helps decide if any subsequent code paths are impossible.

These symbols supply the concrete constant values, types and attributes that determine the truth of the conditions and switch labels inside UT_BSP_DoText. Without them you cannot prove (per MISRA’s unreachable-code requirement) that any branch or statement is impossible to execute.
